items.content_html:
• fixes #27784

The example has two sections: first the problem and second one is the solution using display: flow-root.

Problem

  1. The PR #23506 removed the old hacks and fix using overflow: auto sections but following statement remained, and is out of context now:

    Remove overflow: auto from your .wrapper rule and add display: flow-root and the box will clear.

  2. Looking at the statement other PR #27370 fixed the code in problem section itself using overflow: auto. ðŸ˜†
  3. Now it appears that the problem section is also providing a solution to the issue. Hence the issue author is requesting to remove the solution section all together.

Solution

This PR does following things:

  • remove the overflow: auto fix from the problem section code
  • remove the out of context statement regarding overflow: auto
  • remove the duplicate style rules from the hidden code fences
  • bring better contrast to text inside the blue box
  • make "Float" word in floating box black again (current white colored is not visible)
items.title: fix(CSS): undo a wrong fix in float document

items.content_html:
Description

Update pull() details to include important requirement from the specification that chunks must be enqueued for pull() to be called more than once.

Motivation

MDN Web Docs pull() description is incomplete re details in language of the specification.

Additional details

https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-underlyingsource-pull

This function will not be called until start() successfully completes. Additionally, it will only be called repeatedly if it enqueues at least one chunk or fulfills a BYOB request; a no-op pull() implementation will not be continually called.

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update pull() description

items.content_html:
Description

  • Removed an invalid example for @container
  • Reordered examples to match the keywords listed above
  • Reintroduced a section about container style queries with a note about experimental status

Motivation

  • I'm excited to use container queries, and found the fourth example to be invalid after testing in stable Firefox and Chrome Canary. I could not find a reference to a (condition A) not (condition B) syntax in the CSS spec. Incorrect information cannot be helpful.
  • The keywords are listed as and/or/not, but the examples were not/and/or. It is a small improvement that makes it more logical when having a quick look at this page.
  • I wanted to see what information there was on style queries and could not find any, only to see that section was completely removed instead of showing an "Experimental" preamble. In order to allow for authors to experiment with the feature and provide feedback to vendors, the existence of the feature should not be obfuscated.

Additional details

I'm not privy to internal discussions so the removal of style queries might be justified but regardless, I believe it should be shown. I'm not sure of the correct syntax in the docs to highlight experimental status, so if my contribution is incorrect, I'd welcome feedback to make it better.
items.title: docs(CSS): Clean up @container examples and reintroduce style queries section

items.content_html:
Description

More detailed description of the current issues/inconsistencies: #26088

  • Fix/remove/rewrite some out-of-place paragraphs
  • move examples from the <tr> reference page to the <table> reference page (like it is the case for the other table elements like <td> or <th>)
  • improve minor things like using macros for html elements for example

Motivation

As a reader, it was confusing to me how the examples on the <tr> reference page are directly connected to the element itself. They are in fact general table examples...
There were also paragraphs that fit better on the overall <table> reference page, e.g. mentioning the table section in the learning area.

Additional details

I have been waiting for feedback on the corrections/improvements in the related issue for quite a while now: But I thought I will just start making the improvements and fixes and create a pr.

Personally, I think the other table element reference pages are fine now. However, I somehow have the feeling that there is too much information on the <table> reference page now. Maybe that was the reason why the examples where on the <tr> page? But as already stated, they were too general there.

Perhaps some duplicate/redundant information can be removed. Further suggestions or improvements are welcome.

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #26088
items.title: fix and improve content on reference pages of table elements

items.content_html:
Adding a release note for SVG q length unit:

<svg style="height: 150q; width: 150q; background: red;" x="0" y="0"></svg>
let mySvg = document.createElementNS("http://www.w3.org/2000/svg", "svg");
mySvg.setAttribute("style", "height: 100q; width: 100q; background: red;");
mySvg.setAttribute("x", "0");
mySvg.setAttribute("y", "0");

document.body.appendChild(mySvg);

other changes:

  • Added references to CSS specs for definitions of common length units.
  • Minor cleanup for \<type> reverting

TODO:

  • revert formatting of SVG types

Related issues and pull requests:

  • Parent issue #27759

Bugzilla:

  • BUG-1829269
items.title: relnote(116): SVG q unit supported (defined in CSS length units)

items.content_html:
Description

The PerformanceNavigationTiming.notRestoredReasons property (see Back/forward cache notRestoredReasons API) is finally going to be launched in Chrome 116. This PR adds a reference page for the property, and a guide to using it.

This content is taken from the linked developer.chrome.com page, which will be redirected to MDN once it is live here.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Adds docs for notRestoredReasons

items.content_html:
Description

replace "timing function" with "easing function".

Note: I have not replaced this term in file: files/en-us/mozilla/firefox/releases/55/index.md and files/en-us/mozilla/firefox/releases/65/index.md as they are the Historical Release Notes.

Motivation

See https://www.w3.org/TR/2017/WD-css-timing-1-20170221/, w3c is now using "Easing function" instead of "timing function"

Related issues and pull requests

Continue: #27315, #27811
items.title: chore(css): replace "timing function" with "easing function"

items.content_html:
There was a spec change to make HTMLElement.togglePopover() return a boolean rather than undefined. I started this update on the false understanding that this had been implemented in FF. Not the case there, or anywhere else (yet).

Rather than throw away the work, I have used HTML comments to hide that.

The value this adds is that now the popup is a working live example, which additionally makes it clear that you have to think about what will happen if popovers are not supported (the popover HTML just renders!)
items.title: HTMLElement.togglePopover() live example

items.content_html:
FF116 supports TextMetrics.fontBoundingBoxAscent and TextMetrics.fontBoundingBoxDescent in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1801198

This adds a release note. I also updated the docs with a live example (essentially a live log) and updated to match template.

Other docs work can be tracked in #27758
items.title: FF116 Relnote/docs fontBoundingBoxAscent/Descent

items.content_html:
I am Japanese and my English is not good. First of all, sorry for using Deepl translation.

Description

We found that "cacheable" as written in the PATCH method is inconsistent with the RFC and other documents. This is the fix.

Motivation

This was clearly inconsistent with other documents. The "cacheable" documentation clearly states that cacheability of POST and PATH is "Only if freshness information is included".

However, PATCH says NO. We checked RFC5789, which describes the PATH specification, and found this to be incorrect.

I sent this PR because we believe this will cause confusion for other developers.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Patch method cacheable modified to "No" to "Only if freshness information is included".

items.content_html:
Description

Changed dead Acorn links to working ones.

Motivation

The old links took users to a sign in page, then a 404 not found page. The updated version takes users to the latest acorn homepage.

Additional details

Some Acorn links (eg: https://acorn.firefox.com/latest/styles/iconography.html) still don't function. I couldn't find a clear way to link to the updated page (https://acorn.firefox.com/latest/styles/iconography-q7JqGl5H) that would persist when "q7JqGl5H" is presumably changed in a future page update.

Related issues and pull requests

None
items.title: Fixed dead acorn links

items.content_html:
Description

I added an Accessibility Concerns section to the entry on the datalist element.

Motivation

According to MDN's accessibility expert's presentation, it's best to avoid using this element due to accessibility concerns. Adding this information would help tech professionals become aware of what to use in their products.

Additional details

This is where the change will be made.

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #22958
items.title: datalist: Add a accessibility concerns section

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

items.content_html:
Description

The spec link in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/WebAssembly/Understanding_the_text_format for the binary format was broken. The only alive doc I could find was https://webassembly.github.io/spec/core/bikeshed/#modules%E2%91%A0%E2%93%AA (not exactly sure why the URL is like this but I guess section URLs are like this). This PR replaces the broken link with the correct one.

Motivation

I was disappointed by the lack of docs available for the binary format.

Additional details

Found it here: https://webassembly.github.io/spec/ in the W3C version under "5.5.16 Modules".

Related issues and pull requests

N/A
items.title: Fix WASM format link
